title: Resection is responsible for loss of transcription around a double-strand break in <italic>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</italic>
abstract: Emerging evidence indicate that the mammalian checkpoint kinase ATM induces transcriptional silencing <italic>in cis</italic> to DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) through a poorly understood mechanism. Here we show that in <italic>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</italic> a single DSB causes transcriptional inhibition of proximal genes independently of Tel1/ATM and Mec1/ATR. Since the DSB ends undergo nucleolytic degradation (resection) of their 5′-ending strands, we investigated the contribution of resection in this DSB-induced transcriptional inhibition. We discovered that resection-defective mutants fail to stop transcription around a DSB, and the extent of this failure correlates with the severity of the resection defect. Furthermore, Rad9 and generation of γH2A reduce this DSB-induced transcriptional inhibition by counteracting DSB resection. Therefore, the conversion of the DSB ends from double-stranded to single-stranded DNA, which is necessary to initiate DSB repair by homologous recombination, is responsible for loss of transcription around a DSB in <italic>S. cerevisiae</italic>.
